description: [Status: stable] [Name: useless-return] [Message: Useless return statement at end of function] What it does Checks for functions that end with an unnecessary return or return None, and contain no other return statements. Why is this bad? Python implicitly assumes a None return at the end of a function, making it unnecessary to explicitly write return None. Example def f(): print(5) return None Use instead: def f(): print(5)
